courseTitle: Proseminar in Criminology and Criminal Justice
courseDescription: This course provides students with a broad overview of enduring topics and emerging issues in criminology and criminal justice.  It also explores the history and role of criminology as an academic discipline and criminal justice as an institutional system in American society.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of criminal justice policies
Analyzing case studies in law enforcement

courseDescription: This course covers the policy process as it relates to crime legislation, criminological theory and implications for public policy.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with stakeholders in policy development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the effectiveness of crime legislation

courseDescription: This course is an examination of criminological theory for the advanced student.  The focus is on critical analysis of both contemporary and historical criminological theories.  In order to aid in the development of a critical understanding of theory, beyond understanding the content of central theories, the class focuses on discussion of theory development and testing.  In addition, the class focuses on an understanding of the relationship of one theory to another as well as the state of empirical evidence surrounding each theory.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding empirical evidence in criminological theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theoretical frameworks to real-world scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Facilitating group projects related to criminological theories

courseDescription: This course examines the linkages between social characteristics and crime.  The course concentrates on what we know about the impact of gender, age, race and social class on crime and criminal justice.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings on crime trends
Collaborating with peers on group projects related to crime analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing correlations between social characteristics and crime rates
Identifying patterns in criminal behavior based on demographic data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on the impact of social factors on crime
Organizing research projects on crime and justice issues

courseDescription: This course teaches multivariate statistical techniques to train criminal justice researchers and policy makers to explore the causes and consequences of crime and criminal justices policies.  Although the exact statistical techniques covered may vary, they will typically include multiple regression, multiple discriminate analysis, logistic regression, factor analysis, cluster analysis and path analysis.

courseTitle: Qualitative Methods in Criminology and Criminal Justice
courseDescription: The central goal of this graduate seminar is to enable students to create and critique qualitative research designs focused on contemporary issues in criminology and criminal justice.  A number of qualitative approaches will be covered including field observational research, focused interviews, case studies and content analysis.  The seminar explores techniques, strengths and limitations of these varied qualitative methodologies.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluate strengths and limitations of qualitative methodologies

courseTitle: Advanced Quantitative Techniques in Criminology & Criminal Justice
courseDescription: This course explores advanced statistical techniques commonly used in research on crime and justice.  The major focus of the course will be hierarchical linear modeling (HLM), a diverse set of techniques that extend standard multivariate analysis to accommodate nested data.  Other advanced techniques will also be covered: event history/survival models, time series, etc.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Statistical modeling for crime and justice research

courseDescription: This course examines the links between social structures and institutions, and justice at the individual, neighborhood, city, state and country levels. Students explore the ways in which structures and institutions are both agents of social control and facilitators or initiators of crime. Emphasis will be placed on theories, methodologies and empirical assessments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of social structures and institutions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers on group projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of theories and methodologies

courseDescription: This course provides a foundation of the most important theories and research relating to residential communities and crime. The casual linkages between features of neighborhoods and social disorder will be explored in the context of criminological theories. Students will emerge with sufficient knowledge to develop a class or design a significant research project.

This course explores crimes of the state from a sociological and criminological perspective by examining historical and current cases of governmental crime. This will cover the history, theory and method of the field; controls of and constraints on state crime; and cases of state crime.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching historical cases of state crimes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on case studies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying patterns in state crime cases
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on state crime topics
Organizing research materials on state crimes

courseDescription: Students will develop original research projects on the criminal justice system, police, courts and /or corrections. Projects will be designed to culminate in a publishable paper.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers on research projects
Effective communication with stakeholders in the criminal justice system
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of criminal justice information
Identification of research gaps in the system
Data interpretation for criminal justice research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for completing research tasks

courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce graduate students to life-course perspectives for understanding crime and deviant behavior.  Students discuss the various methodologies, both quantitative and qualitative, most commonly found in studies of the life course today.

courseTitle: Advanced Research Methods in Criminology & Criminal Justice
courseDescription: This course provides students with advanced understanding of issues in criminology/criminal justice research including:   history, philosophy, sociology, epistemology, politics and ethics of social science research; methodological questions of reliability, validity, conceptualization, operationalization, scale construction, data collection methodologies, sampling.

This course examines issues surrounding jail and prison environments in the U.S. Topics include the philosophy of incarceration, inmate rights, inmate (mal)adaptation, misconduct, inmate and correctional officer safety and well-being, classification, rehabilitative programming, and evidence-based solutions and scholarly opportunities aimed at improving the experience of both inmates and staff.

Awareness of inmate and correctional officer safety protocols
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Conflict resolution with inmates and staff
Active listening skills in correctional settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of inmate adaptation strategies
Analytical approach to improving inmate well-being
Developing evidence-based solutions for correctional challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to manage inmate rehabilitative programs
Leadership in promoting inmate and staff safety
Organizing inmate and staff well-being initiatives

courseDescription: This course provides a systematic introduction to the study of queer communities in criminology and criminal justice, while still drawing from diverse academic disciplines, such as sociology, history, and women’s, gender, and sexuality studies. We will first explore the contexts of LGBTQ individuals’ criminalized conduct across time and space, as well as our guiding theoretical lens. We will critically interrogate existing literatures on queer peoples’ victimization as well as their offending. Finally, we will explore emerging public health and education concerns.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying research gaps in victimization studies
Analyzing public health concerns in queer communities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on theoretical frameworks in criminology

This course provides a systematic introduction to the study of gender and crime. We first explore theories, trends, patterns, and pathways, which include gendered contexts of risk, victimization, and offending. We also explore the role of the state, such as in regulating reproduction or in furthering criminalization and surveillance through institutions such as schools, the crimino-legal system, and carceral settings. Other topics, including the experiences of women in criminal justice occupations, are also discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital research tools for crime analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings on gender and crime
Collaborating with peers on group projects in criminology
Communicating effectively with diverse stakeholders in criminal justice
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing gender disparities in crime data
Identifying patterns in criminal behavior by gender
Critically evaluating gendered contexts of risk and victimization
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on gender and crime topics
Facilitating group work on gender-related criminal justice issues
